reversi

Class Node

  • java.lang.Object
    • reversi.Node

  • public class Node
extends java.lang.Object
    A node of a search tree. This class can be used in the implementation of the search tree. The game state, its score and the move that led to this game state are stored in the node.

    • Field Summary

    int moveX,
    int moveY,

        Parameters:
        state - game state
        moveX - the X coordinate of the move
        moveY - the Y coordinate of the move
        movePlayer - the player that made the move

    • Method Detail

      • getDepth

        public int getDepth()
        Returns the maximum depth of the tree. If the node has no children, the return value is 1.
        Returns:
        the depth of the tree

      • print

        public void print()
        Prints the node and all its children. This can be useful when debugging the algorithm. The score of each node is printed.

      • isParent

        public boolean isParent(Node other)
        Checks whether a given node is the parent or parent's parent or parent's parent's parent or ... of this node.
        Parameters:
        other - The node to be checked
        Returns:
        true, if other is one of the parents of this node

      • getMove

        public Move getMove()
        Returns the move that led to the game state stored in this node. When the minimax algorithm has been performed, the move to be done can is the move stored in the optimal child of the root node.
        Returns:
        The move that led to the game state in this node

      • setMove

        public void setMove(Move move)
        Sets the move that led to the game state stored in the node
        Parameters:
        move - The move that led to the game state in this node

      • setState

        public void setState(GameState state)
        Sets the game state saved in this node

      • getState

        public GameState getState()
        Gets the game state saved in this node

      • setParent

        public void setParent(Node newParent)
        Sets the parent node. Note that when using this method, this node is not added to the list of children of the parent node. You should rather use the addChild() and removeChild() methods of the parent node, since they update the information of both the parent and the child node.
        Parameters:
        newParent - the new parent node
        See Also:
        addChild(Node child), removeChild(Node child)

      • getParent

        public Node getParent()
        Returns the parent node. If this node has no parent node, null is returned.

      • addChild

        public void addChild(Node child)
        Adds a child node to this node
        Parameters:
        child - the new child node

      • removeChild

        public void removeChild(Node child)
        Removes a child node

      • getChildren

        public java.util.Vector getChildren()
        Returns the children of this node
        Returns:
        A Vector object containing the children (Node objects)

      • hasChildren

        public boolean hasChildren()
        Checks whether this node has children
        Returns:
        true, if the node has at least one child, otherwise false.

      • setScore

        public void setScore(double newScore)
        Sets the score of the node. The static evaluation of game states must be implemented in the search algorithm, and the results of evaluation are stored into leaf nodes using this method.
        Parameters:
        newScore - the score of the node

      • getScore

        public double getScore()
        Returns the score of the node. If no score has been set, zero is returned. Note that also the real value of the node can be 0.

      • getOptimalChild

        public Node getOptimalChild()
        Returns the optimal child. After scoring the leaf nodes and propagating the results to the root node of the whole search tree, the optimal move is the one returned by the getOptimalChild() method of the root node.
        Returns:
        the optimal branch. If the scores have not been updated correctly and thus the optimal branch cannot be found or if the node has no children, null is returned.
        See Also:
        propagateScore()

      • propagateScore

        public void propagateScore()
        This method equals propagateScore(true) call.
        See Also:
        propagateScore(boolean)

      • propagateScore

        public void propagateScore(boolean maximize)
        Propagates the score calculated in a leaf node to the root of the tree. The result propagates through the tree according to the minimax principle. When the tree has been created and the leaf nodes have been scored, the propagateScore() method of all the nodes one level above the leaf nodes should be called. For example, for the tree shown below, the propagateScore() method of the nodes 1 and 2 should be called after scores have been given to all the leaf nodes. After calling the propagateScore() methods, the optimal move can be retrieved by calling the getOptimalChild() method of the root node. Note: There is no need to call propagateScore() on other tree levels than Level d - 1 as the method works recursively through the tree. 
         +------+
 | Root |                            Level 0
 +------+
     |
    ...
     |
     +------------------+
     |                  |
 +-------+          +-------+
 |   1   |          |   2   |        Level d - 1
 +-------+          +-------+
     |                  |
     +--------+         +-------+
     |        |         |       |
  +-----+  +-----+   +-----+ +-----+
  | 1.1 |  | 1.2 |   | 2.1 | | 2.2 | Level d
  +-----+  +-----+   +-----+ +-----+
        Parameters:
        maximize - If true, the bottommost level is maximization level. If false, the bottommost level is minimization level
        See Also:
        getOptimalChild()
